content.title: Debt Swaps (Debt for Energy, D4E)
content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

This lesson introduces the concept of debt-for-energy swaps (D4E), an innovative financial instrument that allows indebted countries to exchange part of their national debt for investments in renewable energy. The lesson covers how these swaps work, their benefits for both creditors and debtor nations, and their potential to accelerate the energy transition in developing countries. Learners will gain insights into how debt swaps can alleviate fiscal burdens while driving sustainable development and green energy investments.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: debt restructuring√™
concepts.body: Debt restructuring is the process of reorganizing the terms of an existing debt agreement, often to reduce the burden on the borrower, which may include changing interest rates, extending payment deadlines, or reducing the total amount owed.

concepts.title: debt-for- nature swap
concepts.body: A debt-for-nature swap is a financial arrangement in which a portion of a country's foreign debt is forgiven in exchange for commitments to invest in environmental conservation projects.

content.text: Developed countries have pledged to help sustainable energy finance in developing countries but have thus far fallen short of their commitments. On the one hand, many bi- and multilateral donors report challenges in disbursing their funds due to a failure to identify fundable projects. On the other hand, many developing countries report difficulties in accessing available resources due to a lack of capacity and an inability to fulfill specific requirements established by donors or financing institutions. High external debt burdens further hamper the efforts of many developing countries to access finances for setting their economies on a low-emission and climate-resilient path. External debt owed to the private sector, bilaterally to countries or multilaterally to financing institutions, is particularly high in low- and lower-middle-income countries and commonly surpasses the sustainability threshold of 30-50%% of debt relative to GDP. This debt overhang is detrimental to economic growth and an obstacle to ambitious climate goals. Debt-for-Energy (D4E) swaps are a newly proposed financial mechanism designed to support developing countries in achieving sustainable energy transitions while addressing debt challenges. D4E could offer a unique approach where a portion of a developing country's external debt is forgiven or repurchased at a discounted rate in exchange for the country committing to invest in renewable energy projects. However, they remain at a conceptual stage and have not yet been adopted in practice, though they hold great potential. This swap draws inspiration from debt-for-climate and debt-for-nature swaps, adapting these models to address the energy sector’s needs.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Traditional D_SWAP Structure

content.text: Under a D_SWAP arrangement, an entity’s existing debt (government or private sector) is swapped for new debt on more favorable terms. In return, the entity commits to providing systematic support for speciﬁc thematic interventions (e.g., climate, nature, health and education) utilizing the debt service savings from the debt swap. Many SIDS have been early and proliﬁc users of D_SWAPS, with creative transactions in Seychelles (2015), Belize (2021), and Barbados (2022). Recently, larger countries such as Ecuador and Gabon have also executed D_SWAP transactions, primarily focusing on nature
Some Landmark Debt for Nature/Climate SWAPS

Under a debt for nature deal in the Seychelles, the government got a concessional 10-year loan for 15.2 million USD at an annual interest rate of 3 per cent provided by NatureVest (the NGO) plus a grant for 5 million USD provided by philanthropists. These were used to settle USD 21.6 million worth of Paris club debt owed by the Government of Seychelles at a discount of 6.5 percent. Moreover, as part of the deal, the government committed to use its savings to contribute funding for conservation activities for the equivalent of 280,000 USD per year for 20 years and an additional 150,000 USD per year to an endowment fund for future conservation activities. All the relevant financial transactions, as well as the selection of projects and their monitoring, review and verification, are conducted by Seychelles Conservation and Climate Adaptation Trust (the SPV). In November 2021, the Government of Belize together with TNC finalized a debt for marine swap of USD 364 million. Under the swap, a subsidiary of TNC lent funds to Belize to buy back its superbond totaling US$553 million or 30 percent of GDP at a discounted price of 55 cents per dollar. The U.S. Development Finance Corporation provided political risk insurance, allowing the loan to have low interest rates, a grace period of 10 years, and a maturity of 19 years. Belize committed to allocate USD 4.2 million per year until 2041 for marine conservation and expand its Biodiversity Protection Zones. It also created an endowment fund of USD 23.5 million to finance marine conservation after 2041. The swap reduced Belize’s public debt by 12 percent of GDP in 2021 whilst also significantly lowering its debt service costs going into the future.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 2 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Debt for Energy (D4E) Structure

content.text: Like a traditional debt for nature/climate transaction, a D4E transaction involves an entity agreeing to a debt reduction in return for systematic investments in renewable energy (RE). These investment in RE could be for either replacement of existing fossil fuel-based energy production or adding to existing capacity. Either way, the intervention will help to change the current energy mix of the country in favor of RE. A D4E structure can be implemented in both sovereign and private sector settings. Compared to traditional debt swaps however, a D4E instrument offers the added beneﬁt of potential payback – arising from the RE projects. This makes the transaction more beneﬁcial to the respective counterparties, particularly the debtor. Many highly indebted countries with considerable fossil fuel dependency but with significant RE potential stand to benefit from a D4E transaction. A potential benefit of D4E is the balance of payments (BoP) improvement, particularly applicable for fossil fuel-dependent countries that are net fuel importers. Many SIDS could be ideal candidates for D4E transactions due to their small size, over-dependence on fossil fuels, and considerable RE potential.
Bilateral D4E structure

Bi-lateral partners have been the traditional supporters of debt swap transactions –particularly in the areas of health, climate and nature. In a D4E, bilateral partners would extend debt concessions to a country in return for its undertaking to commit systematic resources for the development of RE. This will be particularly applicable for those countries where significant.
Trilateral D4E Structure

The Tri-lateral structure extends the bi-lateral by engaging a third party, commonly an NGO, to function as a ﬁnancial intermediary. The new lender, NGO, or private investor provides funding to the debtor government to repurchase their debt at a discounted rate/obtain debt relief with the condition that resulting debt service savings be channeled to renewable energy projects. This approach is similar to the tripartite debt swap for climate and nature but for two marked differences: (i) the focus is on renewable energy; (ii) the debt service savings (accrued over a period of time) will be capitalized into a new ‘transition bond’ – the proceeds of which will be used to invest in a RE facility.

content.title: Part 3: Financial Structuring of D4E

content.text: The financial structuring of a D4E in a sovereign context comprises of the following steps: Establishing the overall framework for debt swap involving government, NGO, existing creditors, ﬁnancial intermediaries, and other stakeholders such as development partners, political risk insurance (PRI) providers, legal advisors and energy companies (state-owned enterprise and private sector). Agreement on the terms for debt restructuring with existing creditors. Determining the funding requirement for D4E, covering both (i) debt restructuring and (ii) Transition Bond (that covers RE installation3). Chosen ﬁnancial intermediary lending the funding requirement to the NGO, with possible credit enhancement by PRI from development agencies. The NGO, through its Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) on-lending to the government under favorable terms. The government using proceeds to (i) pay down existing creditors under agreed restructuring terms (i.e. debt restructuring component) and (ii) to fund installation of the RE facility (i.e. the transition bond component) through the SPV. Government undertaking institutional, regulatory, and policy changes to support RE development, such as reducing fossil fuel subsidies, setting a price on carbon, and establishing appropriate tariff structures.
Give the above, a D4E structure is seen as being composed of three layers:
Debt restructuring

This is layer common with other types of debt swap transactions particular the D4C and D4N. Debt restructuring entails changing the current profile of claims from creditors to more favorable resulting in lowering the present value of debt. This could achieved by either principle hair-cut, lower interest rates or longer maturity or combination of all. Debt restructuring could be achieved either on bi-lateral basis (i.e. each creditor agreeing to restructuring terms with government) or with the involvement of a third party (such as an NGO) who will provide resources to the government to buy-back the existing loans under restructured terms in exchange of a new loan from the NGO.
Establishment of the RE facility

This considers the investments on a RE facility funded by the Transition Bond. The investment requirement comprise of both physical infrastructure cost as well as the (capitalized) operational cost of the deployment period. Establishment cost as well as the deployment period depends on the type of RE technology considered. For this purpose, three separate technologies viz: solar, wind and geothermal are considered. Their typical cost structures are summarized below:

The deployment period also varies by technology as well as other factors such as the period to obtain necessary approvals, complexity of the project and the ability to procure necessary equipment/input and labor etc. Generally, solar and wind power installations are deployed much faster than technologies such as geothermal. The former sources often deploy less complex structures and are suitable in a wide range of locations. In contrast, geothermal power requires geological conditions suitable for harnessing heat from the Earth as well as drilling deep wells and managing complex systems.
Use of energy project pay-offs

The novel aspect of the Debt for Energy (D4E) structure, in contrast to Debt for Nature (D4N) and Debt for Climate (D4C) structures, lies in the incorporation of pay-offs from investments in renewable energy (RE) projects into the framework. Assuming a positive Return on Capital Employed (ROCE) from the invested projects, the pay-offs can be used in various ways:
a. Prepayment of NGO Loan
If deemed appropriate, the payoffs can be used to pre-pay the loan from the NGO, thereby reducing the debt burden more quickly.
b. Supporting Further Development Initiatives

The pay-offs can be allocated to enhance spending on education, health, social protection, climate adaptation, nature and biodiversity conservation, and climate-resilient physical infrastructure. This broader utility of the D4E framework can be termed as D4E+ and could be one of the more pertinent use of the pay-offs particularly for countries that has significant development finance needs5. The consideration would be particularly applicable in instances where government would use the D4E to augment existing energy capacity with RE. For countries that are looking at a D4E for energy switching purposes the D4E+ would work through adding greater purchasing power direct into the hands of consumers assuming that replacement energy would be at lower costs to that of fossil fuels.
c. Combination of both 1 and 2

This, a hybrid of 1 and 2 above will use the pay-offs to both pre-pay the loan as well as for D4E+ purposes. This method would be more applicable in instances where the transaction size is large and RE resources generate substantial pay-offs.

Another signiﬁcant pay-off from the D4E initiative is the savings on fossil fuel imports. This is particularly relevant for countries who are currently heavily reliant on fossil fuels and are looking at transitioning from fossil fuels to renewable energy. A 100MW of energy equivalent to 4000 hours per year (not always the case) transferred from thermal to renewables, could save approximately 200,000 barrels of oil equivalent (BOE)6. At current oil prices of USD 80 per barrel, this would translate to savings of USD 16 million per year. These BoP savings can be leveraged for various purposes including incorporating into the ﬁnancial structure of a D4E –such through incorporation of a de-risking mechanisms -- thus enhancing the ﬁnancial attractiveness and sustainability of the D4E initiative.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 2 | Part 4
content.title: Part 4: Challenges with D4E tool

content.text: For D4E swaps to be successful, certain conditions must be met. D4E swaps depend on well-designed agreements that clearly define the terms of debt relief and renewable energy commitments. The structure must ensure that investments are made in projects with a high potential for success and that debt relief effectively supports these projects. While it is true that projects with high potential for success are often concentrated in urban areas due to better-developed infrastructure, it is crucial to ensure that D4E swaps also address the needs of rural and remote regions where implementation conditions are more challenging. Successful similar examples from debt-for-climate swap demonstrate that targeted investments in rural areas can significantly benefit these regions. For instance, Kenya's debt-for-climate swap with Germany involves investing in renewable energy and sustainable agriculture projects in rural areas, enhancing food security and rural development.[1] Kenya's renewable energy sector attracts investors due to its robust legal framework, significant renewable resources, and supportive government policies including incentives like feed-in tariffs. These elements, coupled with strong market demand, create a favorable environment for renewable energy investments in both rural and urban areas. As a result of the debt-for-climate swap the Kenyan 300MW Bogoria Silale geothermal power plant is being built in exchange for the settlement of a €60 million loan that Kenya owes Germany . Similarly, Costa Rica's debt-for-nature swaps have funded extensive reforestation and conservation projects in rural areas. These cases demonstrate that with carefully designed agreements and robust monitoring mechanisms, rural regions can indeed receive substantial support and benefit from such initiatives .

Moreover, robust mechanisms must be in place to monitor the use of funds and ensure that renewable energy projects are implemented effectively. Transparency and accountability are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the swap agreements. While D4E swaps have significant potential, they are fraught with challenges that may hinder their widespread adoption and effectiveness: First, D4E swaps are inherently complex transactions involving multiple stakeholders, including governments, NGOs, and financial institutions. The legal, financial, and administrative resources required to structure and execute these deals are substantial, leading to high costs and prolonged timelines. This may deter both creditors and debtors from pursuing them on a larger scale . Additionally, managing transparency, accountability, and ownership is crucial. Ensuring that all parties adhere to high standards of transparency and accountability helps maintain the integrity of the swap agreements. Moreover, establishing clear ownership structures and responsibilities among stakeholders is essential to prevent mismanagement and ensure that the intended benefits of the swaps are realized effectively.

Second, the amount of debt that can be swapped may be insufficient to significantly impact a country's overall debt burden. Debt-for-Climate swap case studies in Barbados, Belize, and Ecuador demonstrate that while these transactions offer short-term benefits, they do not significantly improve the countries' credit ratings or fundamentally alter their debt sustainability profiles. These countries continue to grapple with structural issues, such as weak institutional frameworks and large external imbalances, which constrain their creditworthiness. Third, the long-term financial health and sustainability of D4E depend heavily on the country's ability to adhere to long-term commitments amidst political and economic fluctuations. The extended implementation periods of these projects, often spanning over a decade, make them susceptible to changes in political priorities and economic conditions, which can jeopardize their success. Fourth, debtor countries may lack the institutional capacity to effectively manage large-scale energy projects. To overcome these barriers, a comprehensive approach is needed that addresses the complexity and high costs of transactions, improves financial terms, broadens the scope and impact of projects, and strengthens political and institutional support:

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 2 | Part 5
content.title: Part 5: Strategies To Overcome The Barriers

content.text: Streamline and Scale Transactions

Transition from Bilateral to Multilateral Swaps: Transitioning from individual, bilateral deals to collective or multilateral approaches can significantly increase the scale and impact of D4E swaps. Pooling sovereign debt from multiple creditors allows for larger transactions, providing more substantial debt relief and greater funding for energy transition. Utilize Credit Enhancements: Utilizing credit enhancements, such as guarantees for interest payments, can make D4E swaps more attractive to investors. These guarantees lower risks, attract a broader investor base, and reduce borrowing costs, enhancing the overall effectiveness of the swaps.
Improve Financial Terms and Fiscal Space

Repurchase Debt at Lower Prices: Repurchasing Debt at Lower Prices: Carefully designed secondary market transactions can help repurchase debt at the lowest possible prices, maximizing fiscal relief. This strategy includes planning to avoid price spikes during buy-backs and offering incentives for creditors. Minimizing Financing Costs: Reducing the cost of financing debt buy-backs through partial guarantees or concessional financing can enhance the fiscal space created by D4E swaps. This approach lowers the financial burden on debtor countries, making the swaps more sustainable.[1]
Set Clear Scope and Metrics

Structuring D4E swaps around comprehensive climate and environmental objectives, such as Linking D4E swaps to straightforward, easy-to-monitor metrics is crucial for ensuring transparency and accountability. These metrics provide measurable indicators of success, allowing stakeholders to track progress and evaluate the effectiveness of the investments. Clear metrics help ensure that the funds allocated through D4E swaps achieve their intended environmental and economic outcomes.
Build Institutional and Technical Capacity

Enhancing Local Capacity: Strengthening the technical and institutional capacity of countries to manage DfE swaps is crucial. This includes training government officials, improving financial management systems, and developing robust frameworks for monitoring and evaluation. Integrating into National Budgets: Supporting budgetary spending on energy transition in countries with strong public financial management can streamline the implementation of DfE swaps. This integration helps align the swaps with national priorities and enhances their long-term impact. Developing Monitoring Mechanisms: The UNDP Climate Public Expenditure and Institutional Review (CPEIR) is a diagnostic tool used to assess how a country’s public finances and institutions are aligned with its climate change goals. It examines government spending related to climate action, the effectiveness of institutions managing climate finance, and policy coherence. The CPEIR helps identify gaps, improve budgeting for climate change, and strengthen governance to ensure more effective and transparent use of climate-related funds. It’s especially useful for integrating climate into national planning and budgeting processes. Policy Advocacy and Development: In addition to the measures above, a significant effort is needed to formulate new policies, regulations, and laws to effectively introduce D4E swaps. This involves extensive policy advocacy and advisory services to support governments in creating an enabling environment for D4E swaps. Developing clear legal frameworks and supportive policies is essential for ensuring the smooth execution of these swaps, fostering investor confidence, and securing the long-term sustainability of energy transition projects. Effective policy advocacy can help overcome regulatory barriers and ensure that D4E swaps are integrated into broader national development strategies, thus maximizing their impact on both debt relief and energy transition goals.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 2 | Part 5 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Antigua and Barbuda's Debt for Climate Swap

content.text: Caribbean Small Island Developing States (SIDS) are regions faced with catastrophic vulnerabilities attributed to extreme weather and climate conditions. These events are one of the root causes of the rising debt levels in the region, a shrinking fiscal space, and rapidly declining GDP growth. The country of Antigua and Barbuda is faced with similar economic pressures - with the national debt levels estimated to reach high levels of 1.83 billion USD by 2029 [1]. It has further experienced costly and disastrous climate events – destroying close to 90% of the island’s infrastructure, impacting community members' livelihoods, and disrupting core economic sectors such as the tourism sector. For example, in 2017, the Island was one of the countries impacted by hurricane Irma resulting in damages that caused a 1.1% [2] drop in GDP growth. Typically, hurricanes in the Caribbean SIDS region account for roughly an 8.4% annual GDP loss [3]. This places a country in a vicious cycle of recovery loan requests for natural disasters, pushing countries towards debt distress3 scenarios - with limited resources to spare towards climate adaptation and mitigation initiatives. The Government of Antigua and Barbuda has taken a proactive approach in tackling debt crisis, by positioning itself as an active climate action leader across Alliance of Small Island States and Global Energy Facility (GEF) boards and has further implemented strategic approaches to mitigating climate-imposed debt constraints to ensure that the country is well positioned to receive and scale up access to climate financing. This is demonstrated in the country’s resource mobilization strategy and Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) which elaborate on the adopted multifaceted climate financing approach that leverages funding from multilaterals, such as the Green Climate Fund, GEF, and the Adaptation Fund, and Bilateral and commercial creditors for debt swaps, namely, private sector and philanthropic sources as well as third-party NGOs as implementation agents.

Furthermore, they have forged strategic partnerships with the commonwealth to support capacity building and institutional support initiatives. These efforts have helped maximize opportunities for increased financing through strengthening policy and regulatory frameworks, providing access to international climate finance advisory professionals, facilitating development of compliance and legal frameworks for finance negotiations, and providing technical support in targeted priority program developments. These are some of the key enablers that have facilitated a successful implementation of the debt swap initiative, with regulatory support from the Climate Management Trust SPV ensuring that funds are directed towards sustainable resilience building and liquidity management operations. The primary objectives of the Antigua and Barbuda's debt for climate or clean energy swap initiatives are centered around supporting efforts to build the country’s resilience in managing and adapting to climate risks, supporting emission reduction, and supporting sustained economic growth, adaptation, and development. These innovative financing mechanisms allow creditors to either write off or discount national debt and re-direct the debt payments towards financing climate action. For Antigua and Barbuda these are in alignment with the country’s NDC priorities towards an 86% domestic renewable energy generation and 100% electric vehicle sales target by 2030 stipulated in the energy strategy – translating the debt swap to a debt-for-sustainable energy swap.

Disruptions in energy provision, and damages in energy infrastructure introduces a paradigm of challenges that further affect the well-being of the community, disrupts lives, and widens access gaps for underserved communities. Although this is a tool not yet developed, a debt-for-sustainable energy swap is derived from the same methodology, with priorities focused on funds directed towards developing resilient renewable energy infrastructures, promoting energy security, supporting sustainable human development and economic participation, and contributing towards sustainable development goals. The key lessons derived from the Island are centered around the government’s proactive participatory approach in climate action initiatives, diverse financing options, strategic supportive partnerships with reputable public and private institutions, and compliance roadmap with relevant projects which de-risked the investment environment and improved negotiation conditions for debt swap support. One of the key challenges experienced with debt swaps are centered around fair negotiations, the time-consuming bilateral creditor political approval process, and conflicts with agreements that do not fulfil commercial creditor bottom lines. The debt swaps are better positioned as an innovative multistakeholder financing approach that targets specific sustainable energy and social development interventions and projects, and not complete fiscal capacity support or entire adaptation and mitigation relief support.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: High debt burdens in developing countries constrain economic growth and climate action, highlighting the urgent need for innovative solutions like debt-for-energy swaps to alleviate fiscal pressures and unlock investments in sustainable development.

D4E swaps offer a dual benefit by alleviating the debt burden of developing countries and channeling resources into renewable energy projects, enabling a shift away from fossil fuels and promoting energy sustainability.

Successful implementation of D4E swaps requires strong governance frameworks, technical capacity, and multilateral cooperation to overcome barriers like high transaction complexity, lack of regulatory frameworks, and political instability.
